title: Live Performance Is Back. But Audiences Have Been Slow to Return.
abstract: Attendance lagged in the comeback season, as the challenges posed by the coronavirus persisted. Presenters hope it was just a blip.
byline: By Michael Paulson and Javier C. Hernández

multimedia.caption: “It wasn’t a season of opening post-pandemic, but during a pandemic, and of course, attendance was weak,” said Adam Siegel, the managing director of Lincoln Center Theater, a New York nonprofit.
multimedia.copyright: Charlie Rubin for The New York Times

title: George R.R. Martin Is Finally Getting the Show He Wanted
abstract: “House of the Dragon,” the “Game of Thrones” author’s preferred spinoff, premieres on Sunday night. “It had everything that I thought we needed for a successful successor show,” he said.

multimedia.caption: George R.R. Martin pushed for “House of the Dragon” to be the first “Game of Thrones” spinoff. Eventually, he got his wish.
multimedia.copyright: Kalen Goodluck for The New York Times

title: It Was a Mystery in the Desert for 50 Years
abstract: In a remote Nevada valley, the artist Michael Heizer’s astonishing megasculpture is finally revealed.
byline: By Michael Kimmelman, Todd Heisler and Noah Throop

title: ‘House of the Dragon’ Review: Domesticating ‘Game of Thrones’
abstract: HBO’s long-awaited prequel series has the swords and the dragon flame, the Hand and the Iron Throne. But something’s missing.

multimedia.caption: Matt Smith is among the bickering Targaryens in “House of the Dragon,” a prequel spinoff of “Game of Thrones.”

title: Review: A Ukrainian Orchestra Speaks With Quiet Intensity
abstract: The Ukrainian Freedom Orchestra, convened just a month ago, shows its defiance with sophistication, craft, rigor and subtlety.
org_facet: Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts

multimedia.caption: Moments of national pride: The soloists were wrapped in flags after the Ukrainian Freedom Orchestra’s performance at Damrosch Park.

title: Rewriting Women Back Into Film History
abstract: In shorts from the early 20th century, the stars defy gender stereotypes that would later be standard in Hollywood, as a museum series and box set make clear.

multimedia.caption: In “Mary Jane’s Mishap,” a maid self-destructs, something of a theme in the box set’s films.
In “Mary Jane’s Mishap,” a maid self-destructs, something of a theme in the box set’s films.
In “Mary Jane’s Mishap,” a maid self-destructs, something of a theme in the box set’s films.

title: Mohammed Amer Is a Salad Bowl
abstract: Melting pot? The Houston comedian prefers a different analogy for himself. His new Netflix series, “Mo,” cocreated by Ramy Youssef, should help clarify.

multimedia.caption: “Most of my life has been anxiety, and I think comedy is the way I’ve been able to channel it,” said Mohammed Amer, a Palestinian immigrant whose new series is inspired by his life in Texas.
multimedia.copyright: Eli Durst for The New York Times

title: In Two London Plays, Being Black Means Looking From the Outside In
abstract: Black characters in “Mad House” and “The Southbury Child” endure microaggressions and aspersions. The familiar scenarios hit home for our critic.

multimedia.caption: In Theresa Rebeck’s “Mad House” at the Ambassadors Theater, Akiya Henry, right, plays a nurse witnessing the further breakdown of a family in disarray. David Harbour, left, and Bill Pullman play a son and father viciously at odds.

In Theresa Rebeck’s “Mad House” at the Ambassadors Theater, Akiya Henry, right, plays a nurse witnessing the further breakdown of a family in disarray. David Harbour, left, and Bill Pullman play a son and father viciously at odds.

title: ‘Bad Sisters’ Review: The Family That Kills Together (Maybe)
abstract: Sharon Horgan headlines a twisty, comic take on the avenging-women thriller for Apple TV+.

multimedia.caption: From left, Sharon Horgan, Eve Hewson, Eva Birthistle and Sarah Greene in “Bad Sisters,” which employs humor to give new life to the “Big Little Lies” formula.

title: Blackpink’s Genre-Hopping Return, and 8 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by Blake Shelton, Chloe Moriondo and Madonna.
byline: By Jon Caramanica, Caryn Ganz and Lindsay Zoladz

multimedia.caption: “Pink Venom,” the first single from the K-pop group Blackpink’s next album, gleefully hops from aesthetic to aesthetic.

title: Cambodia Says It’s Found Its Lost Artifacts: In Gallery 249 at the Met
abstract: Cambodia suspects many items were looted and has concerns about a former curator’s business relationship with a Met donor later accused of antiquities trafficking. The museum is seeking evidence of the claims.
byline: By Tom Mashberg and Graham Bowley

multimedia.copyright: via The Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York
via The Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York

title: She Made Glimmerglass a True Festival. Now She’s Moving On.
abstract: During Francesca Zambello’s 12 years as the festival’s leader, she did what she set out to do: took on “complex issues through storytelling and music making.”

multimedia.caption: Francesca Zambello at Glimmerglass in Cooperstown, N.Y. This is her last season as its artistic and general director.

title: Himesh Patel on the Pandemic, Fatherhood and ‘Station Eleven’
abstract: The British actor received an Emmy nod for his role as a freelance writer who takes in a young actress as the world succumbs to a deadly virus.

title: Trisha Brown on the Beach: Catch a Wave of Dancing Bliss
abstract: This year, the Beach Sessions at Rockaway Beach features the Trisha Brown Dance Company in a program of early works.
byline: By Gia Kourlas and Angelo Silvio Vasta For The New York Times

title: Matt Smith on Playing the Rogue Prince of ‘House of the Dragon’
abstract: Smith’s character, Prince Daemon, was an agent of chaos in the series premiere, but “he’s got a strange moral compass of his own,” the actor said.

multimedia.caption: Matt Smith stars as Prince Daemon, a Targaryen with a taste for conflict, in “House of the Dragon.”

title: More Than ‘Weird’: Roku Embraces Original Programming
abstract: The streaming media device company wants to attract more viewers and advertisers to its channel. A coming biopic of “Weird Al” Yankovic is its most ambitious project to date.

multimedia.caption: Quinta Brunson as Oprah Winfrey and Daniel Radcliffe as “Weird Al” Yankovic in “Weird,” which will be available on Roku in November.

title: ‘House of the Dragon’ Premiere: Another Game of Thrones
abstract: Sunday’s long-awaited premiere aimed to create investment in a new royal power struggle while assuring viewers that this was still “Game of Thrones.”

title: ‘Artistic Awakening’ in Benin as Return of Royal Artifacts Attracts Huge Crowds
abstract: As more looted art comes back to Africa, countries have wrestled with the right way to display it. That 200,000 people have lined up for a show suggests Benin has found an answer.

multimedia.caption: Euloge Ahanhanzo Glèlè, a sculptor in Benin, in front of the throne of his ancestor King Glélé at an exhibition of looted artifacts recently returned to the country.
multimedia.copyright: Carmen Abd Ali for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: Euloge Ahanhanzo Glèlè, a sculptor in Benin, in front of the throne of his ancestor King Glélé at an exhibition of looted artifacts recently returned to the country.

title: Abdulrazak Gurnah Refuses to Be Boxed In: ‘I Represent Me’
abstract: Gurnah, who received the Nobel Prize in Literature in 2021, has long rejected attempts to categorize him or his work. “The idea that a writer represents, I resist,” he said.

multimedia.caption: Abdulrazak Gurnah said the impulse to write came after he moved to the U.K. as a young man, “in my homesickness and amidst the anguish of a stranger’s life.” He realized, he said, “there was something I needed to say.”
multimedia.copyright: Adama Jalloh for The New York Times

title: Gary Busey Faces Sex Charges After Appearance at Film Convention
abstract: The actor, 78, was a featured guest at Monster-Mania Con in Cherry Hill, N.J. He was charged with two counts of criminal sexual contact, among other counts, the police said.

multimedia.caption: The actor Gary Busey, who earned an Oscar nomination for his role in the 1978 film “The Buddy Holly Story,” was charged on Saturday, the police said.
multimedia.copyright: Chris Maggio for The New York Times

title: HBO Max Pulls Nearly 200 ‘Sesame Street’ Episodes
abstract: HBO Max took down classic episodes of “Sesame Street” as it prepares to combine with Discovery+. The move came as a surprise to fans, who worried about what it signals.

title: Writers Gather to Read Salman Rushdie and Support Free Speech
abstract: Authors including Paul Auster, Gay Talese, Kiran Desai and others reminded the Midtown crowd that without free expression, “literature is nothing but an echo chamber.”

multimedia.caption: Writers, friends and supporters of Salman Rushdie gathered at the New York Public Library to read from his works at a time of increasing book bans and attacks on speech.

title: Gene LeBell, 89, Judo Champion, Wrestler and Star Stuntman, Dies
abstract: A tough guy who got beaten up by the likes of John Wayne, he had a bottom-line view of his job: “The more you get hit in the nose, the richer you are.”

multimedia.caption: The Hollywood stuntman Gene LeBell in the 1950s, when he was a professional wrestler. He had earlier been an American Amateur Union judo champion.
The Hollywood stuntman Gene LeBell in the 1950s, when he was a professional wrestler. He had earlier been an American Amateur Union judo champion.
The Hollywood stuntman Gene LeBell in the 1950s, when he was a professional wrestler. He had earlier been an American Amateur Union judo champion.

title: Dmitri Vrubel, Who Planted a Kiss on the Berlin Wall, Dies at 62
abstract: A Russian-born painter, he created a mural of the Soviet leader Leonid Brezhnev smooching the East German leader Erich Honecker — and with it a tourist attraction.

multimedia.caption: Mr. Vrubel beside his Berlin Wall mural in 2009. It took on a life of its own, becoming a symbol of Communist decay and an emblem of a freewheeling, artistic Berlin, replicated on T-shirts, mugs and postcards.

Mr. Vrubel beside his Berlin Wall mural in 2009. It took on a life of its own, becoming a symbol of Communist decay and an emblem of a freewheeling, artistic Berlin, replicated on T-shirts, mugs and postcards.

title: A Trial Put Publishing’s Inner Workings on Display. What Did We Learn?
abstract: The book world can be opaque to outsiders. A case offered an unusual glimpse into it, revealing curiosities about the business and details about book deals.
byline: By Elizabeth A. Harris, Alexandra Alter and Adam Bednar

multimedia.caption: A case involving the proposed merger of Penguin Random House and Simon & Schuster wraps up on Friday. A decision is expected in the fall.
A case involving the proposed merger of Penguin Random House and Simon & Schuster wraps up on Friday. A decision is expected in the fall.

title: Delft Tiles Get a Playful, and Sometimes Raunchy, Update
abstract: A new generation of artisans are paying homage to the centuries-old craft even as they subvert it.
byline: By Max Norman, David Chow and Victoria Petro-Conroy

multimedia.caption: Propped between hand-painted tiles by the Dorset, England-based ceramist Aviva Halter, whose animals and flowers evoke traditional Dutch iconography, is one by the British artist Paul Bommer featuring a farmhand admiring what appear to be stalks of asparagus — but are actually penises.
multimedia.copyright: Photographs by David Chow. Styled by Victoria Petro-Conroy

title: Trevor Noah on Trump’s Jailbird Friends
abstract: “Look, if we had more time we could talk about how Trump pretends to be the candidate of law and order. Meanwhile, his friends can fill up an entire prison wing,” Noah joked.
des_facet: The Daily Show with Trevor Noah (TV Program)

multimedia.caption: “Usually you have to run a drug cartel to have this many friends doing this kind of time, so at this point it’s basically El Chapo and Donald Trump — that’s it,” Trevor Noah said.

title: Woman Testifies R. Kelly Sexually Abused Her on Video When She Was 14
abstract: The woman testified at the singer’s federal trial in Chicago that she had been persuaded not to testify against him at his 2008 state trial, which ended in his acquittal.
byline: By Robert Chiarito and Julia Jacobs

title: Abdul Wadud, Cellist Who Crossed Musical Boundaries, Dies at 75
abstract: He performed with classical ensembles, but he was best known for his work with cutting-edge composers and improvisers like Anthony Davis and Julius Hemphill.

multimedia.caption: The cellist Abdul Wadud in 1982. “What Pablo Casals did for the Bach suites,” a fellow cellist said, “I feel like Abdul Wadud did for the new generation of cello in jazz.”
The cellist Abdul Wadud in 1982. “What Pablo Casals did for the Bach suites,” a fellow cellist said, “I feel like Abdul Wadud did for the new generation of cello in jazz.”
